title.raw: 卷一上 光武帝紀 Volume 1a: Annals of Emperor Guangwu

sentences.zh: 世祖光武皇帝諱秀，字文叔，

translations.literal: Shizu Guangwu Emperor personal name Xiu, courtesy name Wenshu,
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Guangwu, posthumously known as Shizu, had the personal name Xiu and the courtesy name Wenshu.

sentences.zh: 〈禮「祖有功而宗有德」，光武中興，故廟稱世祖。

translations.literal: < Ritual: "Ancestors have merit and forebears have virtue," Guangwu restoration, therefore temple name Shizu.
translations.idiomatic: (The Classic of Ritual states: "The founder has merit and the successors have virtue." Since Emperor Guangwu achieved the restoration of the Han, his temple name was Shizu.)

sentences.zh: 謚法：「能紹前業曰光，克定禍亂曰武。

translations.literal: Posthumous name rule: "Able to continue previous work called Guang, able to settle disaster and chaos called Wu.
translations.idiomatic: (According to the rules of posthumous naming: "One who continues the legacy of predecessors is called 'Guang' (Bright), and one who successfully suppresses disaster and chaos is called 'Wu' (Martial).")

sentences.zh: 」伏侯《古今注》曰：「秀之字曰茂。

translations.literal: " Marquis Fu's "Notes on Ancient and Modern" says: "Xiu's courtesy name called Mao.
translations.idiomatic: Marquis Fu's Notes on Past and Present states: "The courtesy name of Xiu was Mao.")

sentences.zh: 伯、仲、叔、季，兄弟之次。

translations.literal: Bo, Zhong, Shu, Ji, brothers' order.
translations.idiomatic: (Bo, Zhong, Shu, and Ji indicate the birth order of brothers.)

sentences.zh: 長兄伯升，次仲，故字文叔焉。

translations.literal: Eldest brother Bosheng, next Zhong, therefore courtesy name Wenshu.
translations.idiomatic: (His eldest brother was Bosheng, and the second was Zhong; therefore, his own courtesy name was Wenshu.)

sentences.zh: 南陽蔡陽人，

translations.literal: Nanyang Caiyang person,
translations.idiomatic: He was a native of Caiyang in Nanyang.

sentences.zh: 〈南陽，郡，今鄧州縣也。

translations.literal: < Nanyang, commandery, now Dengzhou county.
translations.idiomatic: (Nanyang was a commandery; it is now the area around Dengzhou.)

sentences.zh: 蔡陽，縣，故城在今隨州棗陽縣西南。

translations.literal: Caiyang, county, former city in today's Suizhou Zaoyang county southwest.
translations.idiomatic: (Caiyang was a county; its former city was located southwest of present-day Zaoyang County in Suizhou.)

sentences.zh: 高祖九世之孫也，出自景帝生長沙定王發。

translations.literal: Gaozu ninth generation grandson, comes from Jing Emperor produced Changsha Ding King Fa.
translations.idiomatic: He was a ninth-generation descendant of Emperor Gaozu, descending from King Ding of Changsha, named Fa, who was a son of Emperor Jing.

sentences.zh: 〈長沙，郡，今潭州縣也。

translations.literal: < Changsha, commandery, now Tanzhou county.
translations.idiomatic: (Changsha was a commandery; it is now the area around Tanzhou.)

sentences.zh: 發生舂陵節侯買，

translations.literal: Fa produced Chunling Jie Marquis Mai,
translations.idiomatic: Fa was the father of Mai, the Marquis Jie of Chunling.

sentences.zh: 〈舂陵，郷名，本屬零陵泠道縣，在今永州唐興縣北，元帝時徙南陽，仍號舂陵，故城今在隨州棗陽縣東。

translations.literal: Chunling, township name, originally belonged to Lingling Lingdao county, in today's Yongzhou Tangxing county north, Yuan Emperor time moved to Nanyang, still called Chunling, former city now in Suizhou Zaoyang county east.
translations.idiomatic: (Chunling was the name of a township; it originally belonged to Lingdao County in Lingling, located north of present-day Tangxing County in Yongzhou. During the reign of Emperor Yuan, the people were moved to Nanyang, but the area retained the name Chunling; its former city is now east of Zaoyang County in Suizhou.)

sentences.zh: 事具宗室四王傳。

translations.literal: Matters detailed in Imperial Clan Four Kings Biographies.
translations.idiomatic: (The details are provided in the Biographies of the Four Kings of the Imperial Clan.)

sentences.zh: 買生鬱林太守外，

translations.literal: Mai produced Yulin Grand Administrator Wai,
translations.idiomatic: Mai was the father of Wai, who served as the Grand Administrator of Yulin.

sentences.zh: 〈鬱林，郡，今郴州縣。

translations.literal: Yulin, commandery, now Chenzhou county.
translations.idiomatic: (Yulin was a commandery; it is now the area around Chenzhou.)

sentences.zh: 《前書》曰：「郡守，秦官。

translations.literal: "Former Book" says: "Commandery Administrator, Qin official.
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han states: "The Grand Administrator of a commandery was an office established during the Qin.")

sentences.zh: 秩二千石。

translations.literal: Rank two thousand piculs.
translations.idiomatic: (The salary rank was two thousand piculs of grain.)

sentences.zh: 景帝更名太守。

translations.literal: Jing Emperor changed name to Grand Administrator.
translations.idiomatic: (Emperor Jing changed the title to 'Grand Administrator'.)

sentences.zh: 外生鉅鹿都尉回，

translations.literal: Wai produced Julu Chief Commandant Hui,
translations.idiomatic: Wai was the father of Hui, who served as the Chief Commandant of Julu.

sentences.zh: 〈鉅鹿，郡，今邢州縣也。

translations.literal: Julu, commandery, now Xingzhou county.
translations.idiomatic: (Julu was a commandery; it is now the area around Xingzhou.)

sentences.zh: 《前書》曰：「都尉，本郡尉，秦官也。

translations.literal: "Former Book" says: "Chief Commandant, originally commandery commandant, Qin official.
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han states: "The Chief Commandant was originally the Commandery Commandant, a position created by the Qin.")

sentences.zh: 掌佐守，典武職，秩比二千石。

translations.literal: Manage assist administrator, in charge of military posts, rank equivalent to two thousand piculs.
translations.idiomatic: (The duty was to assist the Grand Administrator and oversee military affairs; the salary rank was equivalent to two thousand piculs.)

sentences.zh: 景帝更名都尉。

translations.literal: Jing Emperor changed name to Chief Commandant.
translations.idiomatic: (Emperor Jing changed the title to 'Chief Commandant'.)

sentences.zh: 回生南頓令欽，

translations.literal: Hui produced Nandun Prefect Qin,
translations.idiomatic: Hui was the father of Qin, who served as the Prefect of Nandun.

sentences.zh: 〈南頓，縣，屬汝南郡，故城在今陳州項城縣西。

translations.literal: Nandun, county, belongs to Runan commandery, former city in today's Chenzhou Xiangcheng county west.
translations.idiomatic: (Nandun was a county belonging to the Runan Commandery; its former city was located west of present-day Xiangcheng County in Chenzhou.)

sentences.zh: 《前書》曰：「令、長，皆秦官也。

translations.literal: "Former Book" says: "Prefect, Chief, all Qin officials.
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han states: "The offices of Prefect (Ling) and Chief (Zhang) were both established by the Qin.")

sentences.zh: 萬戶以上為令，秩千石至六百石；

translations.literal: Ten thousand households above be Prefect, rank thousand piculs to six hundred piculs;
translations.idiomatic: (A county with ten thousand or more households had a Prefect, with a salary rank between one thousand and six hundred piculs.)

sentences.zh: 不滿萬戶為長，秩五百石至三百石。

translations.literal: Not full ten thousand households be Chief, rank five hundred piculs to three hundred piculs.
translations.idiomatic: (A county with fewer than ten thousand households had a Chief, with a salary rank between five hundred and three hundred piculs.)

sentences.zh: 欽生光武。

translations.literal: Qin produced Guangwu.
translations.idiomatic: Qin was the father of Emperor Guangwu.

sentences.zh: 光武年九歲而孤，養於叔父良。

translations.literal: Guangwu age nine years and orphaned, raised by uncle Liang.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Guangwu was orphaned at the age of nine and was raised by his paternal uncle, Liang.

sentences.zh: 身長七尺三寸，美須眉，大口，隆準，日角。

translations.literal: Body length seven chi three cun, beautiful beard eyebrows, big mouth, prominent nose, sun horn.
translations.idiomatic: He stood seven chi and three cun tall, with a fine beard and eyebrows, a wide mouth, a high-bridged nose, and a forehead that displayed the 'sun-horn' protuberance.

sentences.zh: 〈隆，高也。

translations.literal: Long, high.
translations.idiomatic: (The term long means high or prominent.)

sentences.zh: 許負云：「鼻頭為準。

translations.literal: Xu Fu says: "Nose tip be Zhun.
translations.idiomatic: (Xu Fu states: "The tip of the nose is called the zhun.")

sentences.zh: 」鄭玄尚書中候注云：「日角謂庭中骨起，狀如日。

translations.literal: " Zheng Xuan Book of Documents Zhonghou note says: "Sun horn means forehead middle bone rise, shape like sun.
translations.idiomatic: (Zheng Xuan, in his commentary on the Zhonghou chapter of the Book of Documents, states: "The 'sun-horn' refers to a bone rising in the middle of the forehead, shaped like the sun.")

sentences.zh: 性勤於稼穡，

translations.literal: Nature diligent in sowing reaping,
translations.idiomatic: By nature, he was diligent in farming.

sentences.zh: 〈種曰稼，斂曰穡。

translations.literal: Sowing called Jia, reaping called Se.
translations.idiomatic: (Sowing is called jia, and harvesting is called se.)

sentences.zh: 而兄伯升好俠養士，常非笑光武事田業，比之高祖兄仲。

translations.literal: But brother Bosheng liked chivalry raising retainers, often mocked Guangwu undertaking field work, compared him to Gaozu brother Zhong.
translations.idiomatic: His elder brother, Bosheng, was fond of chivalrous deeds and maintained a following of retainers; he often mocked Emperor Guangwu for being preoccupied with farming, comparing him to Emperor Gaozu's brother, Zhong.

sentences.zh: 〈仲，郃陽侯喜也，能為產業。

translations.literal: Zhong, Heyang Marquis Xi, able to make industry.
translations.idiomatic: (Zhong refers to Liu Xi, the Marquis of Heyang, who was skilled at managing property and assets.)

sentences.zh: 見《前書》。

translations.literal: See "Former Book".
translations.idiomatic: (See the Book of Han.)

sentences.zh: 王莽天鳳中，

translations.literal: Wang Mang Tianfeng middle,
translations.idiomatic: During the Tianfeng era of Wang Mang's reign,

sentences.zh: 〈王莽建國六年改為天鳳。

translations.literal: Wang Mang Jianguo sixth year changed to Tianfeng.
translations.idiomatic: (In the sixth year of the Jianguo era, Wang Mang changed the era name to Tianfeng.)

sentences.zh: 乃之長安，受尚書，略通大義。

translations.literal: Then went to Chang'an, received Book of Documents, roughly understood great meaning.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Guangwu traveled to Chang'an to study the Classic of History, where he gained a broad understanding of its essential principles.

sentences.zh: 〈《東觀記》曰：「受尚書於中大夫廬江許子威。

translations.literal: "Dongguan Ji" says: "Received Book of Documents from Palace Attendant Lujiang Xu Ziwei.
translations.idiomatic: (The Records of the Eastern Tower states: "He studied the Classic of History under Xu Ziwei of Lujiang, who was a Palace Attendant.")

sentences.zh: 資用乏，與同舍生韓子合錢買驢，令從者僦，以給諸公費。

translations.literal: Funds used up, with roommate student Han-zi combined money buy donkey, ordered attendants hire out, to supply various public expenses.
translations.idiomatic: ("Short on funds, he and his roommate, a student named Han, pooled their money to buy a donkey. They had their attendants hire it out to others to cover their collective expenses.")

sentences.zh: 莽末，天下連歲災蝗，寇盜鋒起。

translations.literal: Mang end, heaven below consecutive years disaster locusts, bandits thieves sharp rise.
translations.idiomatic: Toward the end of Wang Mang's reign, the empire suffered consecutive years of natural disasters and locust plagues, and banditry erupted everywhere with sharp intensity.

sentences.zh: 〈言賊鋒銳競起。

translations.literal: Speak bandits sharp competing rise.
translations.idiomatic: (This means the bandits rose up in competition with sharp vigor.)

sentences.zh: 字或作「蜂」，諭多也。

translations.literal: Character sometimes be "bee", metaphor many.
translations.idiomatic: (The character is sometimes written as 'bee,' serving as a metaphor for their great numbers.)

sentences.zh: 地皇三年，

translations.literal: Dihuang third year,
translations.idiomatic: In the third year of the Dihuang era,

sentences.zh: 〈天鳳六年改為地皇。

translations.literal: Tianfeng sixth year changed to Dihuang.
translations.idiomatic: (In the sixth year of the Tianfeng era, the era name was changed to Dihuang.)

sentences.zh: 南陽荒饑，

translations.literal: Nanyang famine hunger,
translations.idiomatic: A severe famine struck Nanyang.

sentences.zh: 〈《韓詩外傳》曰：「一穀不升曰歉，二穀不升曰饑，三穀不升曰饉，四穀不升曰荒，五穀不升曰大侵。

translations.literal: "Han Shi Wai Zhuan" says: "One grain not rise called Qian, two grains not rise called Ji, three grains not rise called Jin, four grains not rise called Huang, five grains not rise called Da Qin.
translations.idiomatic: (The Illustrations of Han's Odes states: "When one type of grain does not grow, it is called qian; when two types do not grow, it is ji; when three types do not grow, it is jin; when four types do not grow, it is huang; and when five types do not grow, it is daqin (great famine).")

sentences.zh: 諸家賔客多為小盜。

translations.literal: Various families' retainers many be small thieves.
translations.idiomatic: Many of the retainers from various prominent families turned to petty theft.

sentences.zh: 光武避吏新野，

translations.literal: Guangwu avoided officials in Xinye,
translations.idiomatic: To avoid trouble with the local officials, Emperor Guangwu went into hiding in Xinye.

sentences.zh: 〈新野屬南陽郡，今鄧州縣。

translations.literal: Xinye belongs to Nanyang commandery, now Dengzhou county.
translations.idiomatic: (Xinye belonged to the Nanyang Commandery; it is now part of Dengzhou.)

sentences.zh: 《續漢書》曰：「伯升賔客劫人，上避吏於新野鄧晨家。

translations.literal: "Continued Han Book" says: "Bosheng's retainers robbed people, Emperor avoided officials at Xinye Deng Chen home.
translations.idiomatic: (The Continued Book of Han states: "Because Bosheng's retainers had robbed people, the Emperor sought refuge from the officials at the home of Deng Chen in Xinye.")

sentences.zh: 因賣榖於宛。

translations.literal: Because sold grain in Wan.
translations.idiomatic: Consequently, he went to Wan to sell grain.

sentences.zh: 〈《東觀記》曰：「時南陽旱饑，而上田獨收。

translations.literal: "Dongguan Ji" says: "Time Nanyang drought famine, but Emperor's field alone harvested.
translations.idiomatic: (The Records of the Eastern Tower states: "At that time, Nanyang suffered from drought and famine, yet the Emperor's fields alone yielded a harvest.")

sentences.zh: 」宛，縣，屬南陽郡，故城今鄧州南陽縣也。

translations.literal: " Wan, county, belongs to Nanyang commandery, former city today Dengzhou Nanyang county.
translations.idiomatic: (Wan was a county belonging to the Nanyang Commandery; its former city is the present-day Nanyang in Dengzhou.)

sentences.zh: 宛人李通等以圖讖說光武云：「劉氏復起，李氏為輔。」

translations.literal: Wan person Li Tong and others with charts prophecies persuaded Guangwu saying: "Liu clan rise again, Li clan be assistant."
translations.idiomatic: Li Tong and others from Wan used prophetic charts to persuade Emperor Guangwu, saying: "The Liu clan shall rise again, and the Li clan shall serve as their supporters."

sentences.zh: 〈圖，河圖也。

translations.literal: Tu, Yellow River Chart.
translations.idiomatic: (The 'charts' refer to the Yellow River Chart.)

sentences.zh: 讖，符命之書。

translations.literal: Chen, mandate tally book.
translations.idiomatic: (The 'prophecies' refer to books regarding the mandates and omens.)

sentences.zh: 讖，驗也。

translations.literal: Chen, verification.
translations.idiomatic: (The term chen also implies verification.)

sentences.zh: 言為王者受命之徵驗也。

translations.literal: Say be king one who receives mandate sign verification.
translations.idiomatic: (This means they serve as signs and verifications for a king receiving the Mandate of Heaven.)

sentences.zh: 《易坤靈圖》曰：「漢之臣李陽也。

translations.literal: "Yi Kun Ling Tu" says: "Han's minister Li Yang.
translations.idiomatic: (The Kunling Chart of the Classic of Changes states: "The minister of Han shall be Li Yang.")

sentences.zh: 光武初不敢當，然獨念兄伯升素結輕客，必舉大事，且王莽敗亡已兆，天下方亂，遂與定謀，於是乃市兵弩。

translations.literal: Guangwu at first not dare accept, but alone thought brother Bosheng usually connected light retainers, must raise great matter, and Wang Mang defeat death already omen, heaven below just chaos, then with fixed plan, then bought weapons crossbows.
translations.idiomatic: At first, Emperor Guangwu did not dare to accept such talk. However, he reflected that his brother Bosheng had long been associating with adventurous retainers and would certainly attempt a great undertaking. Furthermore, as the omens of Wang Mang's downfall were already appearing and the empire was in turmoil, he eventually joined in the planning and began to purchase weapons and crossbows.

sentences.zh: 十月，與李通從弟軼等起於宛，時年二十八。

translations.literal: Tenth month, with Li Tong cousin Yi etc. rose in Wan, time age twenty-eight.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth month, he rose in rebellion at Wan alongside Li Tong's cousin Li Yi and others; he was twenty-eight years old at the time.

sentences.zh: 十一月，有星孛于張。

translations.literal: Eleventh month, there was star bushy at Zhang.
translations.idiomatic: In the eleventh month, a comet appeared in the constellation Zhang.

sentences.zh: 〈《前書》音義曰：「孛星光芒短，蓬然。

translations.literal: "Former Book" phonetics meanings says: "Bushy star light rays short, fluffy like.
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han: Phonetics and Meanings states: "A comet (beixing) has short light rays and appears fluffy.")

sentences.zh: 張，南方宿也。

translations.literal: Zhang, southern mansion.
translations.idiomatic: (Zhang is a southern constellation.)

sentences.zh: 」《續漢志》曰：「張為周地。

translations.literal: " "Continued Han Treatise" says: "Zhang be Zhou land.
translations.idiomatic: (The Continued Han Treatises state: "Zhang corresponds to the region of Zhou.")

sentences.zh: 星孛于張，東南行即翼、軫之分。

translations.literal: Star bushy at Zhang, southeast travel that is Yi, Zhen division.
translations.idiomatic: ("When a comet appears in Zhang and travels southeast, it enters the divisions of the constellations Yi and Zhen.")

sentences.zh: 翼、軫，楚地，是楚地將有兵亂。

translations.literal: Yi, Zhen, Chu land, this is Chu land will have military chaos.
translations.idiomatic: ("The constellations Yi and Zhen correspond to the land of Chu; this indicated that military unrest would soon occur in that region.")

sentences.zh: 後一年正月，光武起兵舂陵，攻南陽，斬阜、賜等，殺其士衆數萬人。

translations.literal: After one year first month, Guangwu raised troops in Chunling, attacked Nanyang, beheaded Fu, Ci etc., killed its soldiers followers several ten thousand people.
translations.idiomatic: ("In the first month of the following year, Emperor Guangwu raised troops at Chunling and attacked Nanyang, beheading Zhen Fu, Liang Qiuci, and others, and killing tens of thousands of their soldiers.")

sentences.zh: 光武都雒陽，居周地，除穢布新之象。

translations.literal: Guangwu capital Luoyang, resided in Zhou land, remove filth spread new omen.
translations.idiomatic: ("When Emperor Guangwu established his capital at Luoyang, he resided in the land of Zhou; this was an omen of clearing away the old and spreading the new.")

sentences.zh: 光武遂將賔客還舂陵。

translations.literal: Guangwu then led retainers returned to Chunling.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Guangwu then led his retainers back to Chunling.

sentences.zh: 時伯升已會衆起兵。

translations.literal: Time Bosheng already gathered crowd raised troops.
translations.idiomatic: At that time, Bosheng had already gathered a following and raised troops.

sentences.zh: 初，諸家子弟恐懼，皆亡逃自匿，曰：「伯升殺我」。

translations.literal: At first, various families' sons younger brothers feared, all fled escaped self hidden, said: "Bosheng kill me".
translations.idiomatic: Initially, the young men of various local families were terrified; they all fled into hiding, exclaiming, "Bosheng is going to get us killed!"

sentences.zh: 及見光武絳衣大冠，

translations.literal: When saw Guangwu crimson robe large crown,
translations.idiomatic: But when they saw Emperor Guangwu in his crimson robe and large ceremonial crown,

sentences.zh: 〈董巴輿服志曰：「大冠者，謂武冠，武官冠之。

translations.literal: Dong Ba "Chariot and Costume Treatise" says: "Large crown, means military crown, military officials wear it.
translations.idiomatic: (Dong Ba's Treatise on Chariots and Costumes states: "The 'large crown' refers to the military crown, worn by military officials.")

sentences.zh: 」《東觀記》曰：「上時絳衣大冠，將軍服也。

translations.literal: " "Dongguan Ji" says: "Emperor time crimson robe large crown, general clothing.
translations.idiomatic: (The Records of the Eastern Tower states: "At that time, the Emperor wore a crimson robe and a large crown, which was the uniform of a general.")

sentences.zh: 皆驚曰：「謹厚者亦復為之」，乃稍自安。

translations.literal: All surprised said: "Cautious generous person also again do it", then gradually self calmed.
translations.idiomatic: they were all amazed and said, "If even someone as prudent and steady as he is doing this, then we have nothing to fear," and they began to feel more at ease.

sentences.zh: 伯升於是招新市、平林兵，

translations.literal: Bosheng then recruited Xinshi, Pinglin troops,
translations.idiomatic: Bosheng then recruited troops from Xinshi and Pinglin.

sentences.zh: 〈新市，縣，屬江夏郡，故城在今郢州富水縣東北。

translations.literal: Xinshi, county, belongs to Jiangxia commandery, former city today Yingzhou Fushui county northeast.
translations.idiomatic: (Xinshi was a county belonging to the Jiangxia Commandery; its former city is located northeast of present-day Fushui County in Yingzhou.)

sentences.zh: 平林，地名，在今隨州隨縣東北。

translations.literal: Pinglin, place name, in today's Suizhou Sui county northeast.
translations.idiomatic: (Pinglin is the name of a place located northeast of present-day Sui County in Suizhou.)

sentences.zh: 與其帥王鳳、陳牧西擊長聚。

translations.literal: With their leaders Wang Feng, Chen Mu west attacked Chang settlement.
translations.idiomatic: Together with their leaders Wang Feng and Chen Mu, they struck westward at the Chang settlement.

sentences.zh: 〈《廣雅》曰：「聚，居也，音慈諭反。

translations.literal: "Guang Ya" says: "Ju, reside, sound Ci Yu inverted.
translations.idiomatic: (The Guangya states: "Ju means a place of residence; its pronunciation is ci-yu.")

sentences.zh: 」《前書》音義曰：「小於郷曰聚。

translations.literal: "Former Book" phonetics meanings says: "Smaller than township called Ju.
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han: Phonetics and Meanings states: "An area smaller than a township is called a ju.")

sentences.zh: 光武初騎牛，殺新野尉乃得馬。

translations.literal: Guangwu at first rode ox, killed Xinye Commandant then got horse.
translations.idiomatic: Initially, Emperor Guangwu rode an ox into battle; it was only after killing the Commandant of Xinye that he obtained a horse.

sentences.zh: 〈《前書》曰，尉，秦官，秩四百石至二百石也。

translations.literal: "Former Book" says, Commandant, Qin official, rank four hundred piculs to two hundred piculs.
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han states that the Commandant was an office established by the Qin, with a salary rank between four hundred and two hundred piculs.)

sentences.zh: 進屠唐子郷，

translations.literal: Advanced slaughtered Tangzi township,
translations.idiomatic: They advanced and slaughtered the inhabitants of Tangzi Township.

sentences.zh: 〈例曰：「多所誅殺曰屠。

translations.idiomatic: "Now, leading a million troops, if we encounter a city and cannot capture it, what will people say?"

sentences.zh: 〈「遇」或為「過」。

translations.literal: "遇" sometimes be "過".
translations.idiomatic: (The character 'encounter' is sometimes written as 'pass'.)

sentences.zh: 遂圍之數十重，列營百數，雲車十餘丈，

translations.literal: Then besieged it several ten layers, arranged camps hundred numbers, cloud carriages ten plus zhang,
translations.idiomatic: They then besieged the city with dozens of concentric circles of troops, establishing hundreds of camps. Their 'cloud-carriages' stood over ten zhang high,

sentences.zh: 〈雲車即樓車，稱雲，言其高也，升之以望敵，猶墨子云「公輸般為雲梯之械」。

translations.literal: Cloud carriage that is tower carriage, called cloud, speak its height, ascend it to look at enemy, like Mozi says "Gongshu Ban made cloud ladder machinery".
translations.idiomatic: (The 'cloud-carriages' were siege towers; they were called 'cloud' because of their great height. Soldiers would ascend them to observe the enemy, much like the 'cloud-ladders' that Mozi says Gongshu Ban designed.)

sentences.zh: 瞰臨城中，

translations.literal: Look down upon city middle,
translations.idiomatic: allowing them to look down into the city.

sentences.zh: 〈俯視曰瞰，音苦暫反。

translations.literal: Look down called Kan, sound Ku-Zan inverted.
translations.idiomatic: (Looking down from above is called kan; it is pronounced ku-zan.)

sentences.zh: 旗幟蔽野，

translations.literal: Flags banners covered wilderness,
translations.idiomatic: Their flags and banners covered the landscape,

sentences.zh: 〈《廣雅》曰：「幟，幡也，音熾。

translations.literal: Guang Ya says: "Zhi, banner, sound Chi.
translations.idiomatic: (The Guangya states: "Zhi refers to a banner; it is pronounced chi.")

sentences.zh: 埃塵連天，鉦鼓之聲聞數百里。

translations.literal: Dust dirt connected heaven, gong drum sound heard several hundred li.
translations.idiomatic: and the dust they kicked up reached the heavens. The roar of their gongs and drums could be heard for hundreds of li.

sentences.zh: 〈《說文》曰：「鉦，鐃也，似鈴。

translations.literal: Shuo Wen says: "Zheng, Nao, like bell.
translations.idiomatic: (The Shuowen Jiezi states: "The zheng is a type of nao gong, shaped like a bell.")

sentences.zh: 或為地道，衝輣橦城。

translations.literal: Or made tunnels, battering rams tower carriages struck city.
translations.idiomatic: They also dug tunnels and used battering rams and siege towers to assault the city walls.

sentences.zh: 〈衝，橦車也。

translations.literal: Chong, ram carriage.
translations.idiomatic: (The term chong refers to a battering-ram carriage.)

sentences.zh: 詩曰：「臨衝閑閑。

translations.literal: "Book of Odes" says: "Lin-Chong idle-idle.
translations.idiomatic: (The Classic of Poetry states: "The siege towers and battering rams move with steady purpose.")

sentences.zh: 」許慎曰：「輣，樓車也。

translations.literal: Xu Shen says: "Peng, tower carriage.
translations.idiomatic: (Xu Shen states: "Peng refers to a tower carriage.")

sentences.zh: 」輣音步耕反。

translations.literal: Peng sound Bu-Geng inverted.
translations.idiomatic: (The character peng is pronounced bu-geng.)

sentences.zh: 積弩亂發，矢下如雨，城中負戶而汲。

translations.literal: Accumulated crossbows confusedly fired, arrows fell like rain, city middle carried doors and drew water.
translations.idiomatic: A constant volley from their massed crossbows fell like rain, forcing the people inside the city to carry wooden doors over their heads when they went to draw water.

sentences.zh: 王鳳等乞降，不許。

translations.literal: Wang Feng etc. begged surrender, not permitted.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Feng and the others offered to surrender, but Wang Yi and Wang Xun refused to allow it.

sentences.zh: 尋、邑自以為功在漏刻，意氣甚逸。

translations.literal: Xun, Yi self thought merit at water clock, spirit very easy.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Xun and Wang Yi believed that victory was only a matter of time, and their spirits were exceedingly high.

sentences.zh: 夜有流星墜營中，晝有雲如壞山，當營而隕，不及地尺而散，吏士皆厭伏。

translations.literal: Night had falling star fell camp middle, day had cloud like broken mountain, directly above camp and fell, not reach ground foot and dispersed, officials soldiers all suppressed fell.
translations.idiomatic: One night, a meteor fell into the camp. During the day, a cloud shaped like a collapsing mountain descended directly over their camp, dispersing just a foot from the ground. The officers and soldiers were all filled with dread and cowered in fear.

sentences.zh: 〈《續漢志》曰：「雲如壞山，謂營頭之星也。

translations.literal: Continued Han Treatise says: "Cloud like broken mountain, means camp head star.
translations.idiomatic: (The Continued Han Treatises state: "The cloud like a collapsing mountain refers to the 'star of the camp head.'")

sentences.zh: 占曰：『營頭之所墜，其下覆軍殺將，血流千里。

translations.literal: Divination says: "Camp head's place of falling, its below overturns army kills general, blood flows thousand li.
translations.idiomatic: ("The divination says: 'Where the camp-head star falls, the army below shall be overturned and its generals slain, and blood shall flow for a thousand li.'")

sentences.zh: 』」厭音一葉反。

translations.literal: Yan sound Yi-Ye inverted.
translations.idiomatic: (The character yan is pronounced yi-ye.)

sentences.zh: 六月己卯，光武遂與營部俱進，自將步騎千餘，前去大軍四五里而陳。

translations.literal: Sixth month Ji-mao, Guangwu then with camp divisions together advanced, self led infantry cavalry thousand plus, forward away from great army four five li and arranged.
translations.idiomatic: On the jimao day of the sixth month, Emperor Guangwu advanced with his various camp divisions. He personally led a force of over a thousand infantry and cavalry, taking up a position four or five li ahead of the main army.

sentences.zh: 尋、邑亦遣兵數千合戰。

translations.literal: Xun, Yi also sent troops several thousand joined battle.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Xun and Wang Yi also dispatched several thousand troops to engage them.

sentences.zh: 光武奔之，斬首數十級。

translations.literal: Guangwu charged them, beheaded several ten heads.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Guangwu led a charge against them, beheading several dozen of the enemy.

sentences.zh: 〈秦法，斬首一，賜爵一級，故因謂斬首為級。

translations.literal: Qin law, behead one, grant nobility one rank, therefore because call beheaded head rank.
translations.idiomatic: (Under Qin law, for every head taken in battle, a soldier was granted one level of noble rank; consequently, the heads themselves came to be referred to as 'ranks' (ji).)

sentences.zh: 諸部喜曰：「劉將軍平生見小敵怯，今見大敵勇，甚可怪也，且復居前。

translations.literal: Various divisions pleased said: "Liu General whole life saw small enemy cowardly, now see great enemy brave, very can be strange, and again stays front.
translations.idiomatic: The various divisions were delighted and remarked, "General Liu has always been cautious when facing small groups of enemies, yet he is extraordinarily brave when facing a great army. It is quite strange, especially since he insists on taking the lead."

sentences.zh: 請助將軍！

translations.literal: Please help General!
translations.idiomatic: "Let us go and assist the General!"

sentences.zh: 」光武復進，尋、邑兵却，諸部共乘之，斬首數百千級。

translations.literal: Guangwu again advanced, Xun, Yi troops retreated, various divisions together took advantage of them, beheaded several hundred thousand ranks.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Guangwu advanced once more, and the troops of Wang Xun and Wang Yi began to give way. The various divisions together took advantage of the momentum, beheading hundreds or even thousands of the enemy.

sentences.zh: 連勝，遂前。

translations.literal: Consecutive victories, then forward.
translations.idiomatic: Following these successive victories, they continued their advance.

sentences.zh: 時伯升拔宛已三日，而光武尚未知，乃偽使持書報城中，云「宛下兵到」，而陽墯其書。

translations.literal: Time Bosheng captured Wan already three days, but Guangwu not yet knew, then falsely sent person holding letter report city middle, say "Wan captured troops arrived", and pretended drop the letter.
translations.idiomatic: At that time, Bosheng had already captured Wan three days prior, but Emperor Guangwu was not yet aware of it. He sent a fake messenger toward the city carrying a letter that claimed, "The army that captured Wan has arrived," and intentionally had the letter 'lost' so the enemy would find it.

sentences.zh: 尋、邑得之，不憙。

translations.literal: Xun, Yi got it, not pleased.
translations.idiomatic: When Wang Xun and Wang Yi found the letter, they were greatly discouraged.

sentences.zh: 〈憙音許記反。

translations.literal: Xi sound Xu-Ji inverted.
translations.idiomatic: (The character xi is pronounced xu-ji.)

sentences.zh: 諸將旣經累捷，膽氣益壯，無不一當百。

translations.literal: Various generals since experienced accumulated victories, courage spirit more strong, none not one against hundred.
translations.idiomatic: Having achieved a series of victories, the courage of the various generals soared, and each of them fought with the strength of a hundred men.

sentences.zh: 光武乃與敢死者三千人，從城西水上衝其中堅，

translations.literal: Guangwu then with dare-die ones three thousand people, from city west water top charged its center strong,
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Guangwu then led three thousand suicide-squad warriors, crossing the water from the west of the city to charge directly at the heart of the enemy's main force.

sentences.zh: 〈敢死謂果敢而死者。

translations.literal: Dare-die means courageous and die those.
translations.idiomatic: (The term 'dare-to-die' refers to those who are determined and courageous enough to face death.)

sentences.zh: 凡軍事，中軍將最尊，居中以堅銳自輔，故曰中堅也。

translations.literal: Every military matter, middle army general most noble, stays middle take strong sharp self support, therefore called middle strong.
translations.idiomatic: (In military operations, the commander of the central army is the highest in rank; he remains in the middle, supported by elite and battle-hardened troops, which is why they are called the 'central strength' (zhongjian).)

sentences.zh: 尋、邑陳亂，乘銳崩之，遂殺王尋。

translations.literal: Xun, Yi formation confused, took advantage sharp broke them, then killed Wang Xun.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Xun and Wang Yi's formations fell into chaos. Emperor Guangwu took advantage of the momentum to break their lines and successfully killed Wang Xun.

sentences.zh: 城中亦鼓譟而出，中外合埶，震呼動天地，莽兵大潰，走者相騰踐，奔殪百餘里閒。

translations.literal: City middle also drummed clamored and exited, middle outside combined power, shaking shouts moved heaven earth, Mang troops great collapse, fleers each other trampled, ran died hundred plus li interval.
translations.idiomatic: The defenders within the city also burst forth with a thunderous roar of drums and shouts. Forces from within and without joined together, their cries shaking the very heavens and earth. Wang Mang's army suffered a catastrophic collapse; the fleeing soldiers trampled one another, and their bodies littered the ground for over a hundred li.

sentences.zh: 〈殪，仆也，音於計反。

translations.literal: Yi, fall, sound Yu-Ji inverted.
translations.idiomatic: (The character yi means to fall dead; it is pronounced yu-ji.)

sentences.zh: 或作「噎」。

translations.literal: Sometimes be "Ye".
translations.idiomatic: (It is sometimes written as ye.)

sentences.zh: 會大雷風，屋瓦皆飛，雨下如注，滍川盛溢，

translations.literal: Met great thunder wind, house tiles all flew, rain fell like pouring, Zhi River prosperously overflowed,
translations.idiomatic: A violent storm of thunder and wind suddenly erupted, sending roof tiles flying as rain poured down in torrents. The Zhi River overflowed its banks,

sentences.zh: 〈水經曰，滍水出南陽魯陽縣西堯山，東南經昆陽城北，東入汝。

translations.literal: Water Classic says, Zhi water comes from Nanyang Luyang county west Yao mountain, southeast passes Kunyang city north, east enters Ru.
translations.idiomatic: (The Classic of Rivers states that the Zhi River originates from Mount Yao west of Luyang County in Nanyang, flows southeast past the north of Kunyang, and enters the Ru River to the east.)

sentences.zh: 滍音直理反。

translations.literal: Zhi sound Zhi-Li inverted.
translations.idiomatic: (The character zhi is pronounced zhi-li.)

sentences.zh: 虎豹皆股戰，士卒爭赴，溺死者以萬數，水為不流。

translations.literal: Tigers leopards all legs trembled, soldiers struggled to go, drowned dead ones in ten thousand numbers, water because not flow.
translations.idiomatic: Even the tigers and leopards in the army trembled with fear. The fleeing soldiers struggled to cross the river, and so many tens of thousands drowned that their bodies choked the water and stopped its flow.

sentences.zh: 〈數過於萬，故以萬為數。

translations.literal: Number exceeded ten thousand, therefore take ten thousand be number.
translations.idiomatic: (The number exceeded ten thousand, so they are counted in units of ten thousand.)

sentences.zh: 王邑、嚴尤、陳茂輕騎乘死人度水逃去。

translations.literal: Wang Yi, Yan You, Chen Mao light cavalry rode dead people crossed water escaped away.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Yi, Yan You, and Chen Mao fled with their light cavalry, literally riding over the heaps of corpses to cross the river and escape.

sentences.zh: 盡獲其軍實輜重，車甲珍寶，不可勝筭，舉之連月不盡，或燔燒其餘。

translations.literal: Completely captured their army supplies baggage, carriages armor treasures, cannot exceed calculation, carried them consecutive months not exhausted, or burned their remainder.
translations.idiomatic: They captured the entire enemy supply train, including countless carriages, armor, and treasures. The quantity was so immense that it took months to haul it all away, and what remained was eventually set on fire.

sentences.zh: 光武因復徇下潁陽。

translations.literal: Guangwu because again campaigned down Yingyang.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Guangwu then took advantage of the momentum to campaign and capture Yingyang.

sentences.zh: 〈縣名，屬潁川郡，故城在今許州。

translations.literal: County name, belongs to Yingchuan commandery, former city in today's Xuzhou.
translations.idiomatic: (Yingyang was a county belonging to the Yingchuan Commandery; its former city is in present-day Xuzhou.)

sentences.zh: 會伯升為更始所害，光武自父城馳詣宛謝。

translations.literal: Met Bosheng be Gengshi that harmed, Guangwu from Fucheng galloped to Wan thanked.
translations.idiomatic: Just then, Bosheng was murdered by Emperor Gengshi. Emperor Guangwu galloped from Fucheng to Wan to express his apologies and submission.

sentences.zh: 〈父城，縣，古應國也，屬潁川郡，故城在今許州葉縣東北。

translations.literal: Fucheng, county, ancient Ying state, belongs to Yingchuan commandery, former city today Xuzhou Ye county northeast.
translations.idiomatic: (Fucheng was a county and the site of the ancient state of Ying, belonging to the Yingchuan Commandery; its former city is northeast of present-day Ye County in Xuzhou.)

sentences.zh: 以伯升見害，心不自安，故謝。

translations.literal: Because Bosheng seen harmed, heart not self at ease, therefore thanked.
translations.idiomatic: (Because Bosheng had been killed, Emperor Guangwu was deeply unsettled and thus went to offer his formal apologies.)

sentences.zh: 司徒官屬迎弔光武，光武難交私語，深引過而已。

translations.literal: Grand Minister Over Masses officials subordinates welcomed condoled Guangwu, Guangwu difficult joined private talk, deeply cited fault only.
translations.idiomatic: The former subordinates of the Grand Minister over the Masses came to welcome and offer condolences to Emperor Guangwu, but he avoided any private conversation with them, instead taking all the blame upon himself.

sentences.zh: 未甞自伐昆陽之功，又不敢為伯升服喪，飲食言笑如平常。

translations.literal: Not yet self boasted Kunyang's merit, also not dare for Bosheng wear mourning, drinking eating speaking laughing like normal.
translations.idiomatic: He never boasted of his achievements at Kunyang, nor did he dare to wear mourning clothes for Bosheng; he ate, drank, and conversed as if nothing were amiss.

sentences.zh: 更始以是慙，拜光武為破虜大將軍，封武信侯。

translations.literal: Gengshi because of this ashamed, appointed Guangwu be Defeat Barbarian Grand General, enfeoffed Wuxin Marquis.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gengshi, feeling ashamed because of this, appointed Emperor Guangwu as the Grand General for Crushing the Rebels and enfeoffed him as the Marquis of Wuxin.

sentences.zh: 九月庚戌，三輔豪桀共誅王莽，傳首詣宛。

translations.literal: Ninth month Geng-xu, Sanfu heroes together executed Wang Mang, passed head to Wan.
translations.idiomatic: On the gengxu day of the ninth month, the local heroes of the Sanfu region united to execute Wang Mang, and his head was sent to Wan.

sentences.zh: 〈三輔謂京兆、左馮翊、右扶風，共在長安中，分領諸縣。

translations.literal: Sanfu means Jingzhao, Zuo Fengyi, You Fufeng, together in Chang'an middle, separately governing various counties.
translations.idiomatic: (The 'Sanfu' refers to the three capital districts of Jingzhao, Zuo Fengyi, and You Fufeng, which together administered the counties surrounding Chang'an.)

sentences.zh: 淮南子曰：「智過百人謂之豪。

translations.literal: "Huainanzi" says: "Intelligence exceeding hundred people call them Hao.
translations.idiomatic: (The Huainanzi states: "One whose intelligence exceeds that of a hundred men is called a hao (hero).")

sentences.zh: 」白虎通云：「賢萬人曰傑。

translations.literal: "Baihu Tong" says: "Worthy ten thousand people call Jie.
translations.idiomatic: (The Baihu Tong states: "One whose virtue exceeds that of ten thousand men is called a jie (extraordinary talent).")

sentences.zh: 」時城中少年子弟張魚等攻莽於漸臺，商人杜吳殺莽，校尉公賔就斬莽首，將軍申屠建等傳莽首詣宛。

translations.literal: Time city middle youth children Zhang Yu etc. attacked Mang at Gradual Tower, merchant Du Wu killed Mang, Colonel Gongbin Jiu beheaded Mang's head, General Shentu Jian etc. passed Mang's head to Wan.
translations.idiomatic: (At that time, young men in the city, such as Zhang Yu and others, attacked Wang Mang at the Gradual Tower. A merchant named Du Wu killed Wang Mang, and Colonel Gongbin Jiu beheaded him. General Shentu Jian and others then sent Wang Mang's head to Wan.)

sentences.zh: 更始將北都洛陽，以光武行司隷校尉，使前整修宮府。

translations.literal: Gengshi about to north capital Luoyang, take Guangwu acting Sili Colonel, sent before to renovate palace offices.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gengshi, preparing to move his capital north to Luoyang, appointed Emperor Guangwu as the Acting Colonel-Director of Retainers and sent him ahead to renovate the imperial palaces and government offices.

sentences.zh: 〈《前書》曰：司隷校尉本周官，武帝初置，持節，從中都官徒千二百人，督大姦猾。

translations.literal: Former Book says: Sili Colonel originally Zhou official, Wu Emperor first established, holding tally, followed middle capital official subordinates thousand two hundred people, oversaw great traitors crafties.
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han states: The office of Colonel-Director of Retainers was originally a Zhou position. Emperor Wu first re-established it, granting the officer the imperial tally and a force of 1,200 subordinates from the capital to oversee and apprehend major criminals.)

sentences.zh: 後罷其兵，察三輔、三河、弘農。

translations.literal: Later dismissed its troops, inspected Sanfu, Sanhe, Hongnong.
translations.idiomatic: (Later, the military force was disbanded, and the office was tasked with inspecting the Sanfu region, the three commanderies of the Yellow River, and Hongnong.)

sentences.zh: 秩比二千石。

translations.literal: Rank equivalent two thousand piculs.
translations.idiomatic: (The salary rank was equivalent to two thousand piculs.)

sentences.zh: 音義云：「以掌徒隷而巡察，故曰司隷。

translations.literal: Phonetics meaning says: "Because managed subordinates and patrolled inspected, therefore called Sili.
translations.idiomatic: (The Phonetics and Meanings states: "Because the office managed retinue and conducted patrols and inspections, it was called Sili (Director of Retainers).")

sentences.zh: 於是置僚屬，作文移，

translations.literal: Then established subordinates, made written documents,
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon, he appointed his staff and issued official written instructions,

sentences.zh: 〈《東觀記》曰「文書移與屬縣」也。

translations.literal: Dongguan Ji says "Documents moved to subordinate counties" also.
translations.idiomatic: (The Records of the Eastern Tower states this refers to "the distribution of official documents to the subordinate counties.")

sentences.zh: 從事司察，一如舊章。

translations.literal: Engaged in administration inspection, all like old rules.
translations.idiomatic: and carried out administrative inspections exactly according to the established protocols of the former Han dynasty.

sentences.zh: 〈《續漢書》曰：「司隷置從事史十二人，秩皆百石，主督促文書，察舉非法。

translations.literal: Continued Han Book says: "Sili established Assistant Secretaries twelve people, rank all hundred piculs, managed overseeing documents, inspected reported illegalities.
translations.idiomatic: (The Continued Book of Han states: "The Colonel-Director of Retainers appointed twelve Assistant Secretaries, each with a salary rank of one hundred piculs, who were responsible for managing official documents and investigating and reporting illegal acts.")

sentences.zh: 時三輔吏士東迎更始，見諸將過，皆冠幘，

translations.literal: Time Sanfu officials soldiers east welcomed Gengshi, saw various generals passed, all wore headcloths,
translations.idiomatic: At that time, the officials and soldiers of the Sanfu region traveled east to welcome Emperor Gengshi. When they saw the various generals passing by, they were all wearing headcloths,

sentences.zh: 〈漢官儀曰：「幘者，古之卑賤不冠者之所服也。

translations.literal: Han Official Rituals says: "Headcloth, ancient low mean ones not wearing caps those what wear.
translations.idiomatic: (The Ceremonial Protocols of Han Officials states: "The headcloth (ze) was originally worn by those of low status who were not entitled to wear formal caps.")

sentences.zh: 」方言曰：「覆髻謂之幘，或謂之承露。

translations.literal: Dialects says: "Cover hairknot call it Ze, or call it receive dew.
translations.idiomatic: (The Dialects states: "That which covers the hair knot is called a ze, or sometimes a 'dew-catcher'.")

sentences.zh: 而服婦人衣，諸于繡镼，

translations.literal: But wore women clothes, Zhuyu embroidered sleeves,
translations.idiomatic: but they were dressed in women's clothing—zhuyu robes with embroidered short sleeves.

sentences.zh: 〈《前書》音義曰：「諸于，大掖衣也，如婦人之褂衣。

translations.literal: Former Book phonetics meaning says: "Zhuyu, large side garment, like women's outer garment.
translations.idiomatic: (The Book of Han: Phonetics and Meanings states: "The zhuyu was a large side-slit garment, similar to a woman's outer robe.")

sentences.zh: 」字書無「镼」字，續漢書作「䘿」，並音其物反。

translations.literal: Character book no "镼" character, Continued Han Book makes "䘿", both sound Qi-Wu inverted.
translations.idiomatic: (The character 镼 is not found in dictionaries; the Continued Book of Han writes it as 䘿; both are pronounced qi-wu.)

sentences.zh: 楊雄方言曰：「襜褕，其短者，自關之西謂之『䘪䘿』。

translations.literal: Yang Xiong "Dialects" says: "Chanyu, its short ones, from pass west call it "Chongjue".
translations.idiomatic: (Yang Xiong's Dialects states: "Short chanyu robes are called chongjue in the regions west of the pass.")

sentences.zh: 」郭璞注云：「俗名䘿掖。

translations.literal: Guo Pu note says: "Vulgar name Jueye.
translations.idiomatic: (Guo Pu's commentary states: "The common name is jueye.")

sentences.zh: 」據此，即是諸于上加繡䘿，如今之半臂也。

translations.literal: According to this, then is Zhuyu above added embroidered sleeve, like today's half-arm.
translations.idiomatic: (Based on this, it refers to an embroidered short-sleeved jacket worn over a zhuyu robe, similar to the 'half-sleeve' garments of today.)

sentences.zh: 或「繡」下有「擁」字。

translations.literal: Or "embroidered" below has "embrace" character.
translations.idiomatic: (In some versions, the character yong (embrace) appears after 'embroidered'.)

sentences.zh: 莫不笑之，或有畏而走者。
